description:
The overall experience for me was closer to 3 stars, but because they deliver what they advertise, it probably deserves 4 stars.

Doughp is located on the second floor of pier 39. Do a little walking and browsing around. If you know of the staircase that looks like the piano keys, you're going in the right direction!

If you are a die-hard cookie dough lover, then this place will probably satisfy your fantasy of eating pure cookie dough.

There are no eggs so you don't have to worry about the risk of salmonella. This place "looks" like ice cream in that the cookie dough is scooped and can be placed in either a cup or a waffle cone. However, remember that this is cookie dough, not ice cream. If you're looking for ice cream, you should probably try Dreyers at the pier or Ghiradelli Square.

I shared the cookie monster with my partner. We got one scoop in the red velvet waffle cone. Check-in on Yelp and you can get two free toppings. I wanted to try the novelty of this, and as fun as the experience was, I'm not sure if I'm that huge of a cookie dough fan in general.

One scoop was plenty for us; we barely made it through. This stuff is decadent and indulgent in every way possible. After a few bites I was ready to throw in the towel. However, the cookie dough itself was pretty good and the consistency even without eggs mimicked fresh made cookie dough well.

A little too heavy and indulgent for me - which I can't believe I'm saying given that I love sweets and dessert so much. I think I'd rather have my cookie dough baked though. :-) To each their own, I think it's great that this option exists for people who really love it!
author: Liz C.

description:
Great concept but missed the target. The cookie dough would taste a lot better if it were cold instead of room temperature. Bare minimum the drinks should be cold to help quench the sugary dough. Having BOTH the dough and the drinks only offered at room temperature was a total let down.
Came in really looking forward to trying it...leaving less than enthusiastic. Bummer!
...now off to find a COLD drink.
author: Leilani W.

description:
I never really go to Pier 39, the touristy atmosphere it seeps is a turn off for most of us Bay Area locals.  BUT, I happened to be in the area and was looking for a vegan bite to have.  DOUGHP was listed first, as it was closest to my location.  I went in, extremely excited, to try this vegan dough the reviews raved about.  I got there at around 6pm, and they were out.  This was totally understandable to me, once they showed me that they only make a small batch of the vegan dough.  I decided, maybe next time I'm here I will get to try it.

Fast forward to "next time," I'm here a lot earlier, about 1pm.  I ask for the vegan dough and this time they have it.  I almost just went ahead and ordered a scoop out of excitement but I decided to get a sample.  I... couldn't even finish the small sample.  The vegan dough, which I believe was also gluten free (don't quote me on that,) was the weirdest, grainiest texture I had ever had.  The taste was also EXTREMELY underwhelming, it was just regular chocolate chip cookie dough despite the fact I came to this cool spot assuming the vegan options would be just as fun and unique as the omni options.

Had this place been in a different location, I probably could understand a bit more.  But we are in the Bay Area, a prime location for vegan options.  I guess I just had my expectations set too high, but again this was not a good, flavorful experience for me.  I agree with another reviewer, save your time and just go to Cinnaholic for their cookie dough.  They have a basic vegan chocolate chip flavor, but over 20 topping options (which are all also vegan.)  Unfortunately, even store-bought vegan cookie dough was better than this stuff :-(

My rating is specifically for the lack of options and flavor for us veggies.  The staff, on the other hand, are all really nice and welcoming!  The place does have great hospitality.  I would love to see more options implemented for vegans and maybe I'd be willing to try this place again-- I really wanted to love it!!
author: Jessica E.

description: To be completely honest, I just went here for the gram. Also my friend put me under the impression that this place also had ice cream. I was sadly disappointed. I ended up getting the cookie dough monsta on a charcoal waffle cone. After two small bites I was all set. If you're not a sweets person, sharing is highly recommended. The dough had a grainy consistency, at times I felt I was biting into a cube of sugar. I agree as many had mentioned it would have tasted better cold than room temp. A little overpriced for a scoop of dough but I guess the insta worthy pic made it worth it.
author: Amelia L.

description:
So I walked by this place and only after I passed the door did my brain register what I had just read. Safe edible cookie dough? I mean honestly, I've been rolling the dice with the other kind for years, but I had to give this a try. 
I'm glad I did. The staff was friendly and happily shared the process they go through to make the "dough" (hint... it involves sunflower oil.)
I really enjoyed the "this s'more is hella awsome" scoop that I ordered. I probably should have gotten a drink to go with it because who did it get sweet. I wish they had one here so i could try all the other flavors!
author: Christian D.

description:
Hella DOUGHP

I knew this wasn't ice cream and I still wanted to try. With a name like that how could I not? 

Located on the second floor, on Pier 39, DOUGHP resides in a small-ish sized room. There's a couple of seats inside with a little patio by the back. The artwork is great and oh, they even have a little board showing a 1 Star review they got showing someone mistakenly taking their eatery as an ice cream shop instead of just cookie dough.

You know what instantly took my attention? The friendly faces at the counter. The fact that I was offered a sample. I felt like as soon it was my turn that the person helping me would be able to answer any question I had without hesitation. 

But luckily I knew what I wanted. I saw BLUE cookie dough and instantly wanted a part of that. So I ordered a scoop of Cookie Monsta and whoa! Mind blown!

A good one time spot! 

4/5 (four because I think the scoop cost to much at 6.50, and yes I know that I am as in a tourist spot bu still)
author: Alexa T.

description: I've been wanting to try this place out for months, and I finally got the chance this past week when my friends were in town, and I was showing them around fisherman's wharf. The staff was very nice and let us try a couple flavors before making a decision. I'll be honest that I wasn't blown away by all of their flavors, and they only had about 5 options, and I thought there would be more, but we settled on the doughfetti one that had chunks of confetti cake in it. This was amazing, especially since funfetti is my favorite type of cake. It was a little sweet, and 3 of us shared one scoop and it was more than enough! I'll definitely be back to try other flavors!
author: Sonia S.

description:
If I'm being honest, I visited DOUGHP Cookie Dough Bar strictly for the 'gram.

I love ice cream cones and I love cookie dough, so I figured- why the heck not? I cannot stress enough that this is NOT ice cream. It looks like ice cream. It scoops like ice cream. But it is NOT, I repeat, it is NOT ice cream... and I'm okay with that.

I got one scoop of The Original (Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough) on a French Vanilla waffle cone (which had activated charcoal in it), and added peanut butter and chocolate syrup, because why not?

Before digging in, I headed back to their awesome neon sign and took the necessary 'gram photos. The best part about this not being ice cream is that it did not melt in the picture process. Success!

My first bite was amazing, I honestly thought I had died and gone to dessert heaven. It sweet and oh so very rich, so I do recommend grabbing a bottle of water to go along with it (or milk, if you want that milk and cookie vibe). The dough was dope, and the cone was interesting- I didn't really taste the French Vanilla flavour, but it could have just been over powered by the cookie dough.

Overall it was a pretty cool and unique experience. I would go back to try some different flavours, for sure! Maybe after a trip to the gym first, though.
author: Samantha M.

description:
I'm not sure if I came on a bad day or what... but I don't understand the 5 star reviews....

When I got here there was a group of people in front of my sampling and ordering. I patiently waited my turn because I'd hope someone would give me that courtesy when trying a new place. I was wrong.

When it was my turn, another woman walked in. The girl behind the counter decided to help both of us, which is totally ok. But then took the other girls order behind me and proceeded to help her, completely disregarding me. 

The other girl behind the counter finally helped me once she finished with another customer. Service is really a 0/5 at this place. 

Now to the cookie dough...... there were literally very minimum toppings within the s'mores dough. The BEST part about cookie dough is the little treats you fold into it. It also was room temperature (not cold at all). I ended up tossing it after a couple of bites. 

Definitely not worth the $6.50 per scoop.
author: Kyrsten S.

description:
It's a very cute idea, but it's not very tasty. I got the s'mores and my fiancé got the OG. The cookie dough is dry. I got whipped cream on top and only enjoyed the couple bites I had with the whipped cream, the rest went in the trash.

We both said we'd rather it be served cold instead of room temperature, as well as have the option to add ice cream. And my s'mores needed more of the toppings, you could barely tell it was supposed to be s'mores.
author: Shel D.

description:
3.5/5- Rounding up for great service
Came by on a Tuesday night looking for some post-dinner sweets. I've been hearing a lot about edible cookie dough and I more or less had an idea of what to expect. I'm a huge fan of raw cookie dough but the edible cookie dough I've tried never lives up to the raw stuff so gotta keep my expectations in check. I ended up getting the nutella oreo w/ whipped cream & oreo bits in a choco-hazelnut cone.

Positives of this place:
-No line: Ok I know this is far from everyone's experience but there was absolutely no wait on a Tuesday night in the spring.
-Great service. Had a nice conversation about music w/ one of the employees and she was nice about the toppings. She also knew we wanted a nice photo & she put in extra effort to make it look nice.
-Neon Sign: If you're getting edible cookie dough, you're most likely a little basic deep down which means you need a photo w/ a neon sign. Well DOUGHP has you covered.
-Location: Write by the water/hovering over the pier. You can sit on a little balcony and people watch as you gorge yourself on cookie dough
-Cookie dough isn't too sweet
-Employees let you sample
-Variety of flavors: There's a ton of options beyond plain or chocolate chip. Not all of them were great but it's nice to have the option

Neutral/Negatives:
-A bit pricy. $6 for a basic scoop and all the add-ons really pile on the cost though it seems like they also work with a non-profit so price isn't as big of a deal
-Cone is alright. Seems to be made by the same people who make Milkbomb's cones which I didn't really enjoy (at least not the red velvet flavor). The choco-hazelnut was a bit better though still a bit tough.
-Texture: It's cool to try to make the cookie dough look like ice cream but in the end it's just a bit too gritty and dry. But honestly it's to be expected.
-Flavors: Some of the flavors just didn't work too well for me like the matcha w/ white chocolate

Overall, this isn't the place to go to if you want to elevate your dessert palate but it's a fun sweet treat to try at least once.
author: Vivian C.
Natalie D.

description:
*Important* The workers have verified the pronunciation of the store is "dōp" 

Today's order:
* Single Scoop (aka Self Control) $6.50
        * This S'more is Hella Awesome

Pros:
* The location and product are very instagramable
* The view from up here is nice
* Quick service
* The s'more is not über sweet
* The music is chill


Cons:
* S'more is their most popular flavor according to 
   the workers, I don't see why
* We tasted a number of their flavors and they all 
   tasted very similar
* The dough is room temperature, might be better a 
   bit colder
* Pricey for what you get

Neutral:
* A Self Control single scoop was more than 
   enough to satisfy the sweet-tooth of two 
   young adults
* I'd recommend having a more acidic drink (coffee) 
   to complement the sweetness of the dough
author: Dillon T.

description:
This place is DOUGHP (pun intended). 

(FYI this review is from the Fort Mason Off the Grid food pop up)

I love the cookie dough instead of ice cream concept. The flavors are fantastic, Cinnamood and Nut-hella Oreo are my personal favorites. You can also get toppings, and I got caramel sauce. 

However you try them, they are fantastic!
author: Jenée S.

description:
You want to eat cookie dough? Well, let me tell you, DOUGHP got some cookie dough.

I got to try out their activated charcoal cookie dough at a festival which is pretty similar in taste to their original one. It's a bit difficult for me to rate this because I soon realized after digging in that it really isn't "my thing" to eat cookie dough. I'm not too much of a cookie person and even then, I would rather have a cookie. Despite a scoop being quite small, it is very heavy in nature so it feels very filling. It's not cold like ice cream nor is it hot. It's just kinda at a room temperature with a heavy buttery cookiness to it. It really is cookie dough. I can't really say much else than that. It's certainly unique as a dessert and if you enjoy cookie dough, I can imagine that this is definitely your thing.
author: Joshua M.

description:
Overpriced and overrated. I had really high hopes for this place, but the reality is that DOUGHP had a great concept, terrible execution. On top of that, horrendous service lol.

The server was quite the character :-) When we came in, she ignored us and took her time coming to the counter. I don't think a single word was exchanged with me in this whole interaction, just a few looks and grunts in response to my questions.

After I decided on my order, I asked her for a scoop of the Eminem and started pointing towards cones and asking my friends about the flavors, CLEARLY showing that I wanted a cone-- but she hastily scraped together the scoop and dumped it into a cup without even asking. When I went to politely correct her, she just frowned and gave me this exasperated look. Didn't apologize or anything. Slapped my cup on the counter and returned to cleaning up for the night. I figured to just let it go, a flavored cone is a whole $1.50 more anyways.

We sat at their balcony overlooking the stores below. While DOUGHP's interior is adorable and themed like an ice cream parlour, their outdoor tables were filthy, covered in dough crumbs, renegade toppings, and bird poop. It's such a strange contrast to the otherwise cute decor. Maybe they forget to clean out here. 

EMINEM scoop: It's warm. I thought maybe they'd cool the tubs to prevent the dough from going bad, but it's not. And I expected it to be pretty sweet, but there's a tangy, "artificial sugar" aftertaste. The texture is gritty, like they didn't cream the sugar & butter enough. I'm surprised because other reviews are over the moon about their cookie dough!! Inconsistency issue? Idk.

For $6/scoop without a cone, you'd think it would be a generous af serving... Nope, it's just a tiny scoop that's barely the size of a golf ball. You should skip the hassle of driving to Pier 39 and make cookie dough at home that's more affordable and less sickly-sweet.
author: Emmeline W.

description:
I am so glad we finally tried cookie dough! We opted for the peanut butter dough and added m&ms, sprinkles, and had peanut butter sauce drizzled on it! 
It was a dream! I think it's worth trying at least once and if you are a cookie dough fanatic maybe more!
author: Jessy I.

description:
We were walking around San Francisco's Pier 39 when lo-and-behold "Doughp" cookie bar caught our attention. Now we've tasted cookie dough before, but not at full throttle so this was definitely a must try opportunity.

They're actually located on 2nd level next to Crab House. Though they don't serve any ice cream here, it offers same charm and appeal as most creamery, including wall art for social media fanatics. It's very small, and offer limited seating, most customer take it to go.

The dough is completely safe to eat because it's eggless and we counted 6 flavors on hand. Single scoop is $6 and double is $8. Plus handful of toppings .50 cents extra. 

While one of us opted for single cup of cookies n crème, I opted for the smores on red velvet cone ($1.50 extra). With my Yelp check-in I was able to get 2 free toppings with my smores. I got a drizzle of melted marshmallows and sprinkle fruity pebbles.

The idea of eating cookie dough sounded good at first, but as we began to eat more of it, we found it to be just okay and ended up eating half of it. The actual flavors and sweetness were on point, but unfortunately it wasn't our favorite type of dessert. The warm grainy texture was a turn off for me. I would rather have the ice cream version of cookie dough.

The experience was okay. I guess you either love it or hate!
author: Leo C.

description:
This it the first time I've ever had cookie dough (no ice cream, do not be mistaken) and it was an interesting experience. The line can get long at times, but we went around 6pm, so it was not as busy and we got our cookie dough in around 5 minutes.

The staff was nice and helpful and you are able to choose between I think 6 flavors of edible cookie dough. I enjoyed the experience and the aesthetic grass on the wall. 

I learned I don't really enjoy cookie dough, but it's definitely something worth trying!
author: Jessica Z.

description: I have a massive sweet tooth and am particularly a fan of cookie dough so I was excited to try DOUGHP out while in own. There were around 5 or 6 flavors and I was able to sample a couple. I went with the "DOUGHP for HOPE" (although all I tried were fantastic) because not only was it a delicious birthday cake dough, but part of the proceeds go to a good cause- you even get to pick what foundation your purchase goes towards! I thought this was a very cool feature to have at a popular spot. TRUST me when I say one scoop goes a long way; it's easy to get caught in the moment, but cookie dough sinks like a rock haha! The staff was super friendly and the small shop is adorable with an Instagram-worthy neon sign wall.
author: Amy G.

description: Remember when you were a child and your mom would scold you for trying to sneak some leftover cookie dough when you made cookies? Thats what happened to me at least...but fear not, because your cookie dough dreams have now been made because of DOUGHP! They have about 6 flavors to choose from, but I chose their Dough for Hope flavor which was birthday cake. 100% of the proceeds go to a charity and upon checkout, i was given a raffle ticket so that I could choose which charity the proceeds would go to. I get cookie dough and am giving back to the community?! That's a pretty sweet deal! This is definitely a treat...I wouldn't indulge in it often, but I will enjoy it every time I do. It's a bit on the sweet side so it's great to share! We'll be back for more deliciousness very soon!
author: Lynne T.

description: I love the product!!! I LOVE everything about the idea, flavors and taste. Which is exactly why I ordered it. It took over 2 weeks to receive my box (16 days to be exact). I was very disappointed. I even went down to Pier 39 to make a complaint.
author: Olive R.

description:
As a self-diagnosed cookie dough addict, I was extremely bummed out about how the cookie dough tastes here. 

Located on the second floor of the crepe place in Pier 39, doughp is a very small cookie dough shop that also has a few drinks here and there. 

The line usually curls outside the door, but runs through quickly.

Once it's your turn you can sample the four flavors and like an ice cream shop, get it in a cup or cone. The portions in my opinion are really small compared to the price. 

The taste of the regular cookie dough was really grainy from the sugar (I think brown sugar) and did not taste good at all... While eating your small scoop, you're haunted of the acne you'll see tomorrow morning.

I prefer Cinnaholic's vegan cookie dough that costs the same, but is the size of a tub and tastes way better.

Wouldn't be back, but I get why people would come here once just for the instagram aesthetic
author: Elin M.

description: We tried the nutella oreo at the pop-up stand inside the San Mateo County Fair. I was really excited to try this but when I did, I wasn't blown away. I liked the flavor but the scoop just ended up feeling overwhelming after the while. It may just be that there is such a thing as too much cookie dough. It's a really cool concept though...edible cookie dough. I'd say to try it so you say you can and that's about it.
author: Carmen L.

description: Don't get me wrong, the service was fine. But it's crazy that for a super small cup it's $6. This is straight up cookie dough people! Not ice cream, so it's extremely sweet and thick. It sticks to the top of your mouth too, I wish I had a big glass of milk right about now.... it's upstairs above the crepe place, a little hard to find but we managed. Probably won't be back since there are so many better dessert places at the pier. I tried the blondie but the Nutella-Oreo looked good, but the guy said it's sweeter than blondie and I don't do sweets often, I topped mine with cereal and sprinkles when you check in on yelp you get two feee toppings
author: Karah G.

description:
The place is super "instagramable" and cute. I really liked the concept of cookie dough scooped like ice cream in a cup. I decided to try it and share a cup with my friend. 

Because we didn't know if we'd like it, we got the smallest cup size (it was really small, similar to the circumference of a plastic water bottle). They gave 1 scoop and it was $6.50. As we paid at the cash register, I thought to myself, "Wow this is really little cookie dough for the price that I'm paying". 

I feel like I might have been expecting the cookie dough to be "cold" because of the whole "this is like scooped ice cream but in cookie dough form" concept. But when we took our first bite, we noticed that the cookie dough was warm............... Is it supposed to be like that? Secondly, it was soooooo sweet.... TOO sweet. I could feel my teeth grinding on bits of sugar. Again.... Is it supposed to be like this?? We shared the smallest cup and we couldn't even finish it because we got so sick of the sweetness. 

I don't think I'd come back here only because it is WAY too sweet for my liking. Cool concept though!
author: Emily G.

description:
I came on a Saturday and we were lucky that we skipped the long line. Right after we got our cookie dough, the line became super long.

I got the s'mores cookie dough flavor and I liked that it wasn't overly sweet because there was no way I would be able to handle that. However, it was very overly priced for something so simple as cookie dough. It's one of those take a photo for Snapchat and Instagram and probably won't come back after that because the decor is cute and aesthetic.

What really put off me was that there was a swarm of flies near the cash register and the staff didn't try to do anything about it. 

TLDR: not worth the hype
author: Jamie N.

description:
You don't have to worry about your scoop melting because it's cookiedough!

Definitely a place for people who love richness and have a big sweet tooth! I barely finished my cone scoop so for those of you who aren't big on sweets, I recommend you go for a kiddie scoop in a cup because a single cone scoop will be huge.

I think there were more flavors of cones than there were of cookiedough flavors. There was an orange creamsicle,matcha green tea, sugar cone, and chocolate cone left. For the cookie dough, I saw an original, smores, and 2 others. The nutella oreo mixture was the one that I went for and the flavor didn't come through as much as I was hoping. I tried to add to it with marshmallow drizzle on top but that didn't do quite enough for me.

This place is cute and has a good concept so could be a nice treat for a kids birthday or something but I wouldn't bring more than 4 people at a time since there isn't much space in the place.
author: Laura Y.

description:
My gf and I have had DOUGHP twice now and have loved it both times. If you were a child who loved to eat cookie dough no matter what your mom or grandma said... this place is for you. They have many flavors, toppings and cones to choose from. Plus the names of the flavors are super clever!  

Their prices are a little high, but the reason is the company is helping train and support low income individuals in Berkeley. (They make the dough) so I'll pay a little more for that. People helping people makes the world go round!
author: Chris M.

description: This place looked really cool and I was very excited to try it when I saw it. We got two scoops - the Nutella one and the original. I was disappointed that the cookie dough wasn't cold. It was just room temp. I personally eat cookie dough cold or frozen and think it tastes much better. And because this cookie dough is "edible", it's kind of grainy. I didn't think 2 scoops was worth the $11. It was a neat idea, but I wouldn't go back.
author: Kelsey R.

description:
I was so excited to try this place. We showed up a little more than 30 minutes before they closed. I had looked online at all the flavors so I could figure out my exact order before I showed up. When we arrived there were only two trays of dough, neither of which were flavors that were on line (not even the original was there!) 
I get that it was towards the end of the day and the dough ran out, but the workers said absolutely nothing to us. They just looked at us and we had to ask if those were the only two flavors available. They explained nothing to us about size, cup/cone or add-ins, and I just feel like that would be necessary at such a tourist location. 

I got the Nutella Oreo with m&ms I added on because it was either that or a plain dough colored orange and black. 
The dough was very rich, but just tasted like regular cookie dough. No notes or signs of Nutella or Oreo. So I was able to accept I wasn't missing much with all the other missing flavors.  

One scoop is more than enough for one person, after a few bites you're over it. 


The idea of this place is much cooler than the actual place/ product.
author: Brianna A.

description: This was one of the worst cookie dough place in Norcal. The cookiedough taste was awful and it was very overpriced. I got the original thinking that it would be a pretty decent sized scoop, but it was a very baby scoop&the worker said I can get 3 toppings for a dollar, but all she gave me was crumbs on top when I asked for oreo, peanut butter cups, and fruit pebbles. Total came out to be 8 dollars and I just thought it was totally not worth it.
author: Tiffany W.

description: This place is awesome! I love cookie dough so this is a great concept to me. It literally tastes exactly like the homemade cookie dough I make at home and scoop out of the bowl to eat with my fingers, without the raw egg nastiness. I got a single scoop of the original chocolate chip cookie dough and it was enough for two servings. Super rich and decadent, and a really fun treat. Not sure why I am seeing two and three star reviews on Yelp... people have complained that it's too sweet, too rich, too grainy. Have you even had cookie dough before? This stuff is literally exactly cookie dough!
author: Raquel W.

description:
Didn't even know that cookie dough shop exists, but here it is!  The idea of eating cookie dough has been talked about many times.  Most people remember the times where they were "helping" their parents mix the dough and eating the dough while they're not looking :)  Well, that wasn't me.. lol.. but I thought I'll give it a try anyways.  
It's what I would imagine cookie dough taste like.  It's actually pretty good (I got the Nutella one), but just not for me.  It's way too sweet for my taste, I couldn't even finish it.  For first timers, I would suggest sharing one scoop to try it out.  The big benefit is you can eat it slowly because it doesn't melt!
author: Dian K.

description:
My group of friends were at The Myriad drinking when we got a little snacky. Decided to try Doughp on Saturday, September 16th around 5pm.

We decided to Fully Commit: 3 scoop ($15). I believe the flavors we wanted were The OG, Eminem, and Amber Rose. They were out of Eminem, so we decided to get Lemon Chili instead. Since we were fully committing anyways, we decided to Dough It Up ($1.50), which meant we get three toppings. I believe we got: Butterfinger, Heath Bar, and Cookie Crisps. The cookie dough was good, but I don't think this was up my alley. A tiny bit of cookie dough here and there is fine. Or mixed with ice cream. But to eat three scoops of it? It was too much. I needed something to provide relief from the texture as it was just dry and doughy. The toppings didn't really help as they were dry as well.

Cute concept. Great for people who adore cookie dough. But for me? I think I'll stick to just having it in my ice cream from time to time.
author: Elena N.

description:
Doughp is one those dope ideas that sound great on social media, but once executed, will be the worst idea someone's ever had. I may be biased because I've never been a fan of cookie dough, so I wasn't completely sure what to expect from this place. For $5 I got a huge scoop of cookie dough in a waffle cone. I opted for the regular flavor, and after 4 bites, I already knew I couldn't take anymore and really considered seeing my dentist. 

Perhaps if the dough was cold, it may have been better, but it just tasted like chewy sugar? If you want to come and see what the hype is about, I wouldn't advise you against it, but I'd definitely recommend sharing just one with another friend instead of buying your own and potentially wasting your money. The place had a lot of instagram worthy setups, so for that alone, it may be worth it for some people.
author: My N.

description: I came across Doughp's booth at the 50 Shades of Charcoal event that took place at Soma StrEat Food Park. The employee was scooping cookie dough into a cone (or cup) with toppings as if it were ice cream. The two flavors available were chocolate chip & nutella, but the specialty black cookie dough was like chocolate chip without the chips. I got my scoop topped with rainbow sprinkles & it was visually intriguing as well as a textural party in my mouth. I loved the thick, mostly smooth consistency. Flavor was not overbearingly sweet. I'm not hugely into cookie dough, but let's just say I saw a girl with two scoops instead of one & she definitely made the right choice.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Frankly, I was super disappointed. My expectations may have gotten the best of me, but I can't be the only one who expects cookie dough served like ice cream to be chilled. This stuff was room temp, almost warm. We got the M&M flavor and Snickerdoodle flavors, neither of which were super great. The M&M was definitely better, as the chocolate morsels distracted from the whole experience. But the Snickerdoodle, ah man, this was just gross. Not super cinnamony, and has streaks of butter throughout. Was not a fan. At all. And to make matters worse, the cute neon sign was dismantled, making our experience here pretty terrible. Would not go back or recommend, plenty of other places do edible cookie dough better, and for a fraction of the cost.
author: Ava C.

description: Love that this is on pier 39. We were able to sample all of their cookie dough flavors. To share, my bf & I got the m&m cookie dough & cinnamood. We like to get 1 scoop, 2 flavors (just so we don't waste) and we topped it with sprinkles & caramel inside of a red velvet waffle cone. Could literally eat this all day if I could. They even have a yelp incentive if you check in!
author: Tiara P.

description:
Good. But felt a little disappointed that it wasnt ice cream even though I knew what it was... mind tricks. Also was very sweet... only ate half a scoop. But was tasty.
Food wise it was a 4.
Service wise a 3. The cashier was a straight B! Little patience. Was rolling her eyes. 
Forgot her name... but I can descibe her
author: Alyssa P.

description:
With maturity comes lower risk behavior, like not eating raw eggs mixed into raw cookie dough.  However, the allure is still there, so opting for the salmonella-free version from Doughp is a nice compromise.  The scoops are really filling, hence you probably only need one.  And two non-gluttonous people could probably even share that one scoop.

S'mores Cookie Dough w/ Fluff & Lucky Charms Marshmallows: This was so indulgent!  The raw cookie dough tasted just like raw cookie dough, though the texture was a bit firmer.  I liked the chocolate chip and graham crackers, but didn't really notice the marshmallows much.  However, that was an easy problem to solve by adding Fluff and Lucky Charms Marshmallows!  The toppings are essential, since the base dough tends to be a little light on the mix-ins.
author: Adam B.

description:
My boyfriend and I first tried Doughp when they had a pop up shop at the San Mateo county fair, and it's tasted exactly how I imagined it. Delicious. Like licking the cookie dough batter off the wooden spoon. Yum! We met the owner who was so friendly and energetic, we just had to come and visit the shop itself!

It was amazing! Luckily we came on a Tuesday afternoon so there was no wait. (I thought it would be busy no matter what day/time) It was just as delicious as the first sample I tried weeks ago! If you simply just love cookie dough, you have to try it. It is Uh-mazing!!!
author: Sarah C.

description:
I don't know why the workers are so rude and angsty. They do not say hello and welcome customers. They said absolutely nothing to me or the people in front  of me. They refused to offer the lady in front of me because they "had no clean spoons" which is fine, but she did not even apologize or seem to care. Also the ladies hair was super messy and falling all in the cookie dough. 
The  shop had flies flying around. 

The actually cookie dough was good! I got the classic, and it was pretty good. 
Aside from the horrible service, this place was good!! But I don't think I'll ever come back. It's super expensive cause it's trendy or whatever but just go to the grocery store and buy cookie dough there.
author: Emily G.

description:
Please read why I star this a 1. Reason being is I stayed in line for a long period of time and to find out it is not ice cream nor is it yogurt. It's actually just cookie dough, there was no ice cream, just cookie dough serviced on a cone!....

Lol, that's why I gave this place 5 stars.
author: Kuan H.

description: We were so excited to try DOUGHP that we took a trip back to Pier 39 just for this purpose. We had been there a few days before but hadn't seen it (it's kind of tucked away upstairs near Crab House). I was with 2 cookie dough fanatics so when we got there at opening time (10am) and the doors were locked, we we're a little disappointed. The guy behind the register made no effort to open up or get things in order quicker. So after looking in the windows we decided to walk around to give him more time. We came back around 10:20 and the doors were finally open. He didn't greet us, ask if we had any questions, or apologize for being closed earlier. We ordered and went out back to eat our goods. Now, let me say, the dough is delicious. However, at this price point ($6 for a single scoop, add on toppings/flavored cones/sauce) it's about $8.50. Ouch. Although it was good, we couldn't finish it. I mean let's be real...when you eat cookie dough from a batch you're baking you really only need a couple bites. Also, they don't sell milk, only coffee. Kinda baffling as we all know cookie dough loves milk. I really think this idea would be better suited in ice cream. Like all the different doughs in vanilla ice cream would be much easier to eat. Just sayin. This was a fun experience but I think if I were to go back I would definitely have to share a scoop with someone.
author: Kanani K.

description:
DOUGHP is dope !

I was ecstatic to try out something new and cookie dough scoops definitely fitted that category. 

I love the combo of creations you can make with the various toppings,  flavored cones , and different cookie dough. 

I went with the classic cookie dough on a red velvet cone with sprinkles and my sweet tooth was already satisfied :D.

This place is also very insta worthy and there are outlets to charge your phones while you snap those pics. 

Kelsey was serving me that day when I came and she is so warm, friendly, and inspiring. You go girl!
author: Brenda B.

description:
I have mixed feelings about writing this review. On one hand, what I had was good (really good!). On the other, I just wasn't expecting what actually transpired (which is, me not really feeling the "cookie dough" movement. Let me explain.

All my life (or as far back as I could remember), I've been all about that cookie dough life. I rocked hard with the cookie dough, not because I was a risk taker (you know, that salmonella risk), but I just loved the taste. Always told myself I could eat cookie dough for days! And I always order cookie dough ice cream. I just found it delish!

And thus, the time finally came for me to taste what I had been craving for years! So I loaded the twins up in the car, and we drove on down to this spot, all in anticipation (well, anticipation on my end...the twins could care less). Anyways, I was finally ready to have my world rocked by this dope dough (see what I did there).

Thankfully there was no line and the sales associate was sweet as can be. I wasn't really impressed with the flavors that day, so I asked to taste a couple. I ended up with the vegan oatmeal one. I also selected the Cookie Monster, because why not!?! I could barely maintain my excitement in the deliciousness! And finally (FINALLY!!), I get to take my first bite.

And then...nothing. I mean, I just felt something was off. Maybe it was because what I was eating was room temperature and I'm used to eating things in containers and/or that "appear" like dessert with ice cream, so my mind had a hard time comprehending their not being any ice cream (just dough). It was just weird and very anti-climatic from  my end...and a bit disappointing.

So I write all this to say, that this place isn't bad, it's just important to keep your expectations in line. That, and I can't handle that much cookie dough. Like maybe if it was broken up by some ice cream, then yea. But the straight cookie dough on a cone/in a bowl was a bit much even for me and my sweet tooth. But the flavor is good, customer service rocks, and hopefully there's ice cream to be added in the near future to blast this concept thru the roof (and if not, at least it's pretty good cookie dough).
author: Tracy T.

description:
After reading some of the other reviews, I have no idea why so many are mentioning the neon sign or how it's a great place for Instagram posts. I didn't think of that at all when I went. I was there for one reason: to eat cookie dough!

You either get it or you don't when it comes to dough. As a kid I liked the dough more than the cookie. As a teen I once made myself sick from "sampling" too much dough. I gave it up after that, and now someone has opened a fantasy paradise for cookie dough-lovers that doesn't use eggs (no more fear of salmonella, yay!). 

The place is cute, and in a great location at Pier 39. I knew I just wanted to try the original. If I went again maybe I'd try some of the other flavors, but original was great. I really like this dough! I think some people are expecting cookie dough ice cream, especially because they see you can get it in a cone. It is NOT ice cream, and it's not cold. It is just like cookie dough. So that is why I say: know if you like cookie dough before you get one. If you never cared for it, you won't like this. I personally had no desire to try it in a cone, or with toppings. But to each his own! 

Service was good. It was friendly but a tad slow. I wasn't there at a time where there was a really big line though, so it didn't take too long.

Like almost everything in San Francisco, it is expensive. I imagine it must cost them an absolute fortune to rent that place in such a busy tourist area.  I won't dwell too much on price. Why? Because since moving to CA I have been just flabbergasted at almost all the prices on virtually everything. I mean everything. I literally take pictures of prices at the grocery store. The gas station, etc. Doughp is no different, it's no worse, and I'm actually getting used to the prices anyway. Everything is almost double what I'd pay where I came from in the midwest, like it or hate it. It won't change so I might as well not complain.

The small serving for me personally was perfect. Cookie dough is thick and rich and sweet. Everyone is different but I couldn't handle more than a small most likely. I had just had lunch so I will take that into account, but after the small I  felt almost a little disgusting. 

I'd say if you like cookie dough, go for it!
author: Erika B.

description:
Stumbled upon this place on accident. I've always wanted to go to a cookie dough place, but never been in a town that had one. This was essentially a bucket list item for me.

The lady working there was super nice and happy to explain and give suggestions. My husband and I got two scoops with marshmallow drizzle and sprinkles. It was sooo good. My only regret was that I wasn't able to visit again before we left so we could try more combinations.

Most def worth a visit to try out!
author: Jennifer J.

description:
For all you dough-heads out there this might be your SF spot. The downside, you have to suffer the throngs of tourists at Pier 39. The upside, there are sea lions close by to help you forget about them. 

The dough is smooth and not overly sugary given what it is.  Could use a bit more chocolate in the mix. But it was tasty. It's upstairs FYI, almost like they didn't want you to be able to find it. Like a Legends of Zelda secret room.
author: Toby F.

description:
After seeing endless videos of dō in NY I was pretty excited to learn SF has a cookie dough place too. The Myriad is a fun stop anyway and was the perfect place to put a small stand. 
The variety of flavors they have is decent (not comparable to dō) although they unfortunately did not have all of them when I visited, one of which I was already planning on getting. 

I tried the s'mores and matcha doodle, both of which are delish! They don't refrigerate the dough which, although it adds to that extra fluffy texture, takes away from some of the gleeful, nostalgic quality of eating it. The portions are pretty hefty and I would have had issues finishing it in one sitting. At $6 it's definitely on the pricey side, but a worthwhile occasional treat.
author: Kim B.

description: This place was great! It's different because you take a bite from it and expect it to be cold like ice cream but it isn't! The cookie dough was pretty good, a little bit heavy but perfect if you have a sweet tooth and was something different from ice cream for a change!
author: Joanna C.

description: Checked the website and it said they had GF cookie dough. When we arrived the staff said it was frozen and that she would need to let it defrost. We were going to dinner and indicated that would be perfect and we would return after dinner. When we came back the staff said they only had the taster for the gluten free dough. We repeated what they said earlier and they checked again but were only able to find the taster. Advice: try to call ahead and see if they will have the GF version in store
author: Arrieyana C.

description:
I walked past this place on what I think was there grand opening at Pier 39.  I saw the sign and knew I had to have it.  Unfortunately, the line to get in stopped me in my tracks.  I walked away with a sad face and empty belly.

A couple of night's later I happened to be walking by and Boom! no line.  We went in and were greeted by the friendly staff.  Unfortunately, the friendly staff informed me that they were out of almost everything so I was forced to buy the s'mores.

What I like about cookie dough is it doesn't melt, so I ordered some to go and took it back to my hotel.  I had time to shower and hop in bed before eating it.  It was good, but not the chocolate chip I was hoping for.

I couldn't tell you what I paid, but the portion size was fine for an adult.

If we had a Doughp in my town I would definitely give it another try.
author: Kisha M.

description: The store looked nice. Loved the "legit cookie dough" neon light sign. However, the cookie dough was not good. The taste is overwhelming. I threw the cookie dough in the trash. If anything it does do for nice pictures. You're better off getting ice cream or cookies at a different place. This place is overpriced and overrated. Don't let these pictures fool you. You're most likely going to throw it in the trash too unless you love the taste of cookie dough and can eat a whole tub-full.
author: Christina C.

description:
This space used to be Cup n Cake before changing to Doughp. I have been curious about this place for a bit, especially about the cookie doughs.

Why not today to tey their cookie doughs I thought, so indeed I did along with a cup of cappuccino. The price is high on the scale, with a half cup of cappuccino at $6.00 ( even though the guy there was explaining what was in the cappuccino) While he made my coffee I ask what was the flavor of Secret Santa. He told me  and offer to give me a taste. I liked the peppermint taste so opt for the 2 scoop (whopping $8.00 for two scoops!)

Overall, I was happy I was able to satisfy my curiosity but not happy about my wallet. Well what can you say, it is located in a touristy place. Even so, even if not the location, the price is still too high for my taste.
author: Jen M.

description: Great spot for cookie dough! They have a little deck that looks out on pier 39. They didn't though have any sample spoons for us to be able try the different flavors. Also no child size option.
author: Natalya D.

description: the cookie dough here was soo good. They have custom cone flavors and toppings along with different flavors of cookie dough. I wish there were more flavors of cookie dough available (only about 5 total), but i cant complain. The service was actually really awesome and it's kind of pricey, but it's worth it for sure.
author: Marigny L.

description:
Portion was very small for the price. 

Taste was nothing special compared to the store bought cookie doughs. 

Waffle cone was alright. 

The employee scooping the cookie dough is way too happy. Employee by the register could use a bit more energy. Spoons are located by the registers, grab one bc the staff will not tell you.
author: Char D.

description: I wasn't expecting much out of this place, but I gotta say that this cookie dough was pretty good! I've honestly never had raw cookie dough so I can't accurately compare the two tastes, but essentially it tasted like how you'd expect--cookie dough! The flavor (Blondie) wasn't highly concentrated in flavor or anything (I expected an unnatural/artificial flavor), but was rather very smooth tasting and delicious! At that time they were only serving the flavor Blondie, but in different rainbow colors to celebrate Pride Month! Thats okay though, it just means I gotta visit another time!! I do think the toppings were essential though because the texture got a bit boring after a while. We also purchased a Nutella latte which they served with Illy coffee (I really enjoyed that as well! Yummmm). They were both a bit pricier than I'm used to, but it's expected for Pier 49.
author: Allison B.

description:
Normally I try my best to be punny or channel my inner dad to make jokes but my job's already been done for me here - DOUGHP, It's in the name, so I mean what else needs to be said?!

It was actually an adventure getting here. So fair warning to all-parking is nuts here. The meters are all "special event" meter parking aka THE METERS ARE $7. We dug around every crevice of my car and came together for enough coins to last us 14 golden minutes. We R A N down the block, entered Spark Social, and searched for DOUGHP's cute lil' stand and to our delight found there to be no line. The wonderful woman working the stand let us sample each one and to no surprise, the chocolate chip cookie dough was for sure the best. My friends weren't fans of the matcha snickerdoodle, but I enjoyed it! The taste and texture resembles cookie dough so perfectly that it sort of freaked me out to be honest. Like, I felt like whenever I took a bite, I could hear my mom in the background screaming, "YOU'RE GONNA GET SALMONELLA FROM THE RAW EGGS!!!!!!!" Well mom, it is now 2017, here is cookie dough that I can eat without you yelling at me for (and if you're reading this mom, let's go here sometime okay).
author: Maleah M.

description:
We walked past this place while exploring the pier. I did a double take as we walked on and said to my sister "...Is that....is that what I think it is?!" she paused and replied "Yes....yes it is..." 

Cookie dough is her favorite. Cookie dough everything and anything. It being her birthday trip of course I was on the lookout for anything she might like so -of course- we had to double back and get us a scoop of the cookie dough. 

THERE IS A Check-in OFFER PEOPLE! Don't forget to use it like we did!

We sampled the cookies n crème one first. I am not a cookie dough fantic like my sister so I decided this treat wasn't for me after that first taste. Although it was good, it's just not for me. I tasted the Nutella one and I liked it a bit better (a double chocolate chip cookie dough would have been sooo good!) and we shared a small cup ($6). 

I am so glad I got to experience the trendy scoopable cookie dough and like my tagline says "I did it for the review"....

If you like cookie dough or sweets in general I think everyone should come try a bite of this dough. Or grab a coffee while your bestie gets the 'dough and both of you can sit outside on their tiny private patio.
author: Evangelina R.

description: I was actually really disappointed by DOUGHP. The staff was great and there's a big flavor assortment but ~$6 for one scoop is ludicrous. My friend ended up eating only half because the dough is very dense and not nearly as enjoyable as real cookie dough or plain out ice cream.
author: Brendan H.

description: The dough was good but they did not have a variety of flavors. Only 4 to choose from and plane dough to mix in toppings. I had the white chocolate with raisins.
author: Hard Taco I.

description:
Heard about DOUGHP through social media and newspaper articles. Was pretty anxious to try it out and see what it was all about.

It's located in The Myraid, which has a bunch of different businesses located in it, DOUGHP being one of them. The staff was very helpful with explaining the concept of DOUGHP and sampling different flavors. I tried the Oreo cookie flavor and s'mores one. Instantly like the s'mores. They only serve you one scoop of dough, which is still too much. 

I honestly wasn't sure what the heck to expect. My mind was thinking ice cream I guess, but it was just cookie dough on a cone. I got a red velvet cone with the s'mores flavor.

First few bites were alright. But I could barely take more than about 10 bites before getting full and just about over the whole concept. The one scoop was way to dense and after awhile, it started getting gross and unappetizing. 

Price: $5-6 a scoop (depending what you get) and then adding toppings on it is extra as well. I didn't get any extra toppings so I am not sure how much that would have been. Honestly, it is too expensive for what it is worth. Save your money! 

This was definitely something to experience, but not something I will ever go back to try again.
author: Michael T.

description:
My sister and I shared 2 scoops of s'mores and pumpkin spice for around $8 and some other friends got oreo.   We honestly should have gotten 3 or 4 scoops for the 6 of us to share.  It was extremely yummy but dessert overload. 

The consistency of pumpkin spice was more like thick brownie or cake batter than cookie dough.  I had really looked forward for the matcha flavor one but they weren't serving it that day.  I was very sad...
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I went here on opening day and stood in line for over an hour waiting. Its located in a market hall that seems to try to mimic the huge gourmet food courts they have in NY. I tried the Amber Rose flavor. I actually wasn't a huge fan. I need to come back and try other flavors. 

Also I feel like I am going to just stick with eating dangerous uncooked cookie dough in the middle of the night per usual process.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Similar to Do of NYC, except you don't have to wait in a long line! They say that it is not a health hazard to eat but both my friend and I got stomach aches later in the evening after sharing a scoop, you have been warned! 

Cool concept overall but it is honestly like eating pure sugar. I guess some people are into that. Try baking them at home and you'll see that a scoop can produce probably produce 15 or 20 cookies - that's how much sugar and carbs you are consuming.
author: Elisa L.

description:
I've never been a fan of eating cookie dough straight out of the mixing bowl. But since the nice lady at Doughp's Spark Social location offered me some free tastes, I decided to try it. It was better than I was expecting. Still gritty and leaving tire marks on your tongue -- but good.

The employee noted that most people opt for the original chocolate chip cook flavor. The also had Oreo and s'mores flavors, yet I found the straight up unadulterated buttery flavor of the original to be most enjoyable (this is coming from an Oreo fiend). I wished that the scoop was slightly more chilled rather than room temperature but this might not matter to most. Now thinking of it, a tall glass of cold milk would've hit the spot!

The single scoop is really filling and shareable. I couldn't see myself eating anything more than one scoop. I believe they have topping and cones but that's getting into XXX territory.
author: Michael H.

description:
Located in the Myrid food mall.  They offer 4-5 types of raw cookie dough, your choice of toppings, and some baked cookies.  This particular location was a mess!  It looks like a disorganized kitchen and I questioned the quality.  Presentation is everything!  The flavor signs were hand written and looked rubbed off.  The actual cookie dough was good.  This location is priced at $5 a scoop for a decent size.

Personally (like others have suggested), I don't think this is going to take off like the cupcake craze.  They should offer more with the cookie dough.  For example; cookie dough chocolate covered truffles, fresh cookie dough I can bake at home for a party, cookie dough ice cream sandwich.  Or an option like the rolled ice cream/cold stone craze that would allow you to make your own cookie custom cookie dough based off of 3 plain bases.
author: Alan H.

description: My daughter wants to know why we didn't come up with the amount of cookie dough that is eaten in our household! All I can say is great idea, dough was fabulous, great selection and the idea of providing toppings was pretty cool! We will be looking for shops near us!
author: Marielle V.

description: That Saturday at noon was a perfect time to try out one scoop of raw cookie dough on a cone.  It's better for me to be at DOUGHP first than to wait in a very long line which has been disappointing two days after.  I now take the time to thank Kelsey W. for the latest food creation of the future, one that never melts like frozen yogurt or ice cream!  My scoop of the first visit is amber rose cookie dough on a creamsicle cone.  I only taste the sweetness of the cookie dough, but I couldn't feel the flavor of the rose water.  Still, I like the raw cookie dough that is eggless, which is vegan.  Going to the Myriad and into DOUGHP is better than going to any bakery shop for some baked cookies.  Would be a dopey idea, but it's worth trying something different if and only if it's healthy for anyone.
author: Jimmy C.

description: I get it.  Cookie dough is a thing.  My favorite ice cream is cookie dough ice cream.  This is an interesting concept.  It's like ice cream, but it's all cookie dough.  It's served room temperature in a cone.  The first few bites were good, but at the half way mark (of just one scoop), it was just too rich and too sweet.
author: Jon G.

description: I went here for the first time with my gf and a friend. The overall experience was as expected... long line, people taking pictures and a replication of an ice cream shop. We were limited to two samples, which I respect because people would otherwise try them all and hold up the line. The cookie dough itself was good, but nothing out of this world. I really like that they also served espresso. This compliments the cookie dough very well! I would recommend giving this place a try if in the area and if you have a sweet tooth.
author: Kyler K.

description:
Had to roam over her because it's so close to the house, and fortunately ran into no crowds.

The product itself is good!  I think the problem many may run into is getting overwhelmed by the sweetness of the large ice cream-style scoops of cookie dough. Honestly, a half scoop is enough to satisfy a sweet tooth before you feel sick to your stomach from eating pure butter and sugar. 

I wonder if this trend is sustainable. I'm sure it'll get a lot of business from one-time "I just had to try it" visitors. Perhaps doing a combo with ice cream would break up the intensity of the flavors.
author: Lydia L.

description:
This cookie dough is sooo good. I just can't stop thinking about the smooth texture and the rich sweet taste of this magical dessert. It seriously blows away anything you've tasted off the kitchen counter as a kid. 

My favorite flavors will always be the chocolate goodness of the OG and S'mores. However, Kelsey's creativity for new flavors continue to amaze me every time I visit. I've had everything from matcha to lemon to rose' cookie dough from here and it never disappoints. 

I've been to the Spark Social pop up a few times but this new location that they opened is so fun with the graffiti and neon lights. It's at the Myriad food court where you can even grab a beer and some Poke' before dessert. 

If you have an insatiable sweet tooth like me, take a break from ice cream and give this tasty dessert a try. You'll thank me later.
author: John H.

description:
I love cookie dough. When I found out about doughp, I couldn't wait to try it! Although its a trek to get to the Castro, it's soo worth it. 

I've tried these flavors: 
THE OG: chocolate chip - your basic choco chip! 
S'MORES: marshmallow + graham crackers + choco chips - probably my go to flavor. 
YOU JELLY? peanut butter with jelly! . 
OREO FASHO: crushed oreos - I love anything oreo. 
NUT-HELLA OREO: MY ABSOLUTE FAVE! nutella and oreos are a match made in heaven. Please make this a regular! 

I personally haven't tried the dough in a cone. I took two scoops of nutella oreo home to sit in the fridge overnight. I personally really liked it this way! I ended up finished both scoops in one sitting because 1. It was so good. 2. I couldn't help myself. 
 
It's not made for everyone, but I suggest everyone give it a try! :)
author: Arielle R.

description:
Calling all cookie dough lovers! I enjoyed this place. The worker was friendly and helpful in making the best choice. I can't remember the name but we got something along s'more with birthday cone topped with marshmallow creme and coconut.
The location is great because you can grab other foods and play the pinball machines! Great date spot if you're unsure of what to do.
author: Jenny C.

description: We'd been wanting to try cookie dough for a while but didn't realize there was one at a place we frequent! So happy this is at Pier 39 now. Dough is delicious. I had the S'more and other members of my party had the original and the Eminem. Would definitely go back, cute shop and yummy dough!
author: Katherine N.

description:
I'll start by saying that the cookie dough was really good, but not for the price, which is why I'm only leaving 3 stars. I paid 6 dollars for 1 scoop, which was not even a full scoop. Basically, I paid 6 dollars for a half scoop of cookie dough. You're better off buying cookie dough at the store. You'll get 20 times as much for the same price. 
The cookie dough itself tasted like a legit fresh batch of cookie dough. I tried a few of the flavors, but Nutella was my favorite. The waffle cone, on the other hand, I could have done without. It tasted sort of like a fortune cookie. 
I don't think I'll be trying this place again, but I'd definitely recomend it to somebody who hasn't tried it. It was good, just not worth the money.
author: Sanela S.

description:
Dope af! Cookie dough is definitely one of my kryptnoites..it's been a while since I've indulged, so this was a wonderful surprise. It reminded me of one of those videos you see of awesome food on Facebook only to find out it's in NYC (they all are..ugh). But this was across the street from me! 

I got the cold brew is bae and it was delicious!!!
author: Aria S.

description:
It's great to try but not something I'd go to for desert or have a craving for.

They have a decent area so you can actually try a variety of different things.

I only ordered one scoop but it was enough for two people to share because its not too addicting.
author: Donnah A.

description:
My 5 year old, Ruby, and I attended the grand opening of DOUGHP on 9/14. It was a fun time and worth waiting for.

There are 3 sizing options: one scoop, two scoops, and three scoops. The scoops are generously sized; I can eat with the best of them and two scoops was definitely more than enough for me. The prices are $6, $10, and $15 respectively, which I gotta say made me say, "Whoa. That's steep."

I got a scoop of "Eminem" (M&M cookie dough) and "The OG" (chocolate chip) in a Birthday Cake cone. Both doughs were really good, though not as sweet as I expected (which was probably for the best). "Eminem" was a little skimpy on the M&Ms. I didn't like my cone - it tasted like coconut or artificial fruit flavoring or something, not at all like cake (it occurs to me the scooper may have given me the Fruit Loops cone by mistake, considering how fruity it tasted). 

Ruby got "Eminem" in a Red Velvet cone, with sprinkles. She loved every bite, and I also liked the piece of cone she gave me. One scoop was bountiful for the child. If I can make a suggestion: a kids size scoop would be a great idea. 

In addition to what we tried were cones of several other flavors as well as a good selection of toppings and drizzles (I almost got a caramel drizzle but restrained myself).

There were several flavors but we decided to go with the basics. I was curious to try a couple of the other flavors but they weren't giving samples at the opening. Not sure if they will regularly, though I recommend it (feel free to limit to 2 per person, if you do, DOUGHP). A couple of the flavors I could not bring myself to order without trying because the descriptions were questionable. One was chili lemon which...I couldn't imagine how that would taste good as cookie dough but it must be good to someone! Another was "Amber Rose" which I heard described as rose and elderberry, I believe. I've had both flavors in ice cream but in my mind that would be hella floral/perfume tasting in cookie dough. 

Looking forward to going back and seeing what new flavors they have in the future. Knowing there are tasty staples like "The OG", though, I know I'll always leave happy.
author: Liz G.

description:
Who eats their cookie dough knowingly there is raw egg? 
*Raises hand*

DOUGHP solves this problem as there is EDIBLE cookie dough without worrying about Salmonella. Thanks guys!

I had the opportunity to try it out during SOMA's Ice Cream Showdown. There were a TON of competition, but because each offered something different and unique, it was really a showcase of the different options. 

I opted for a Red Velvet Ice Cream Sandwich with one scoop of Smores Cookie Dough. Believe it or not, it costed me about $15. That's a whole ramen I could get :(

The ice cream sandwich was good, just good. It didn't take me to the orgasm level yet though. And the scoop of cookie dough was just depressing in my opinion. It was way too sweet and the texture was a bit off. I prefer to have my raw cookie dough. A really good improvement they should consider is freezing/cooling their dough so that it at least mimics somewhat of ice cream. I found it odd to be having a lukewarm dessert treat on a super sunny day. 

Fifi isn't about the DOUGHP life.
author: Fiona L.

description: Moi aime cookie dough so when I saw this I knew I had to try it. My little brother and I got the original flavor which was really good. The place inside looked really cool and unique. The people working where ok, and I didn't think the cone tasted that good. But besides that it was really good.
author: Nathan O.

description: Cannot write a more positive review for this place. The line out the door went extremely quickly and they let you tasted as many flavors as you want before ordering. They also had a nice assortment of flavors which is cool considering how monotonous cookie dough could be.  I'm a local to so getting down to Pier 39 can sort of be a pain, but its definitely worth the journey there!
author: Mandy G.

description:
Do you remember that one kid who loved cookie dough ice cream and would pick out the cookie dough bits? Or that one kid who would eat way too much cookie dough before it even hit the oven? Let's be honest, you were that kid . . and because of that I recommend that you try this place. 
Not only is the concept simple yet creative, but they offer a pretty wide variety of cookie dough. Just the other day I saw a pumpkin spice option! You also have the choice to eat it from a bowl or a cone. The cones vary in price depending on the type you choose. You can also customize your dough with one or two or 10 of their many topping choices. Great alternative to ice cream. Less messy and doesn't melt!
I honestly didn't think I would like it, but I ended up really enjoying it. Cool location & neat desserts! Definitely worth a try, at least once, especially if you love dessert! I give it about a 3.5-4. Guy who served us was pretty nice too. He gave us a discount on our cones!
author: Christian N.

description: This is a great place if you want something different and familiar at the same time. Really like the name and the service at this location at Pier 39 was great, they let us try all of the types of cookie dough they had there. Since we checked in through Yelp we got 2 free toppings, Reese's PB and coconut flakes. It was a good combination to the Nutella Cookie Dough! The portions were great, not too much but at first we couldn't finish just one scoop, we had to wait a while before eating the dough again. I would come here again but would prefer to try different places.
author: Dominik K.

description:
This was an absolute must try. It was such a great and unique experience. 

That being said...I went with two friends and we all felt sick to our stomachs after. Maybe because we hadn't eaten for a few hours before. My bf got 2 scoops and couldn't finish half, my other friend got a scoop and cone and felt ill, and I got the gluten free dough on a coffee and threw up on the way home a few hours later. 

Just be warned. We felt a lot better after eating an hour and half later. So maybe eating before would have helped all of us?
author: Erika A.

description:
If you're like me and can't help but eat raw cookie dough while your baking, this is the place for you! I got to try doughp at SPark social. I got a scoop ($6) salted caramel dough in a cup and bought a cone in the side ($0.50). The dough was exactly what I wanted it to be: moist, flavorful, filled with chucks of pretzels, and topped with caramel. 

Reason I'm taking off a star is because the price. I wish this place was more affordable. $6 for a scoop seems steep to me. I remember trying a place similar in New York called Do and paying only $4. I also saw they sell dough ice cream sandwiches for $9. In New York, it was only $5. Huge difference! I can't ever see myself paying $9. But Doughp is lucky because they're the only ones doing what they're doing right now in the Bay Area, at least that I know of. So they can charge whatever they want lol. Hopefully when they start getting more business they can adjust the price.
author: Lexi R.

description:
First off, I love me some cookie dough! Who doesn't? While I was about ten piers away from this place when I realized a cookie dough store had just opened, we quickly put on our walking shoes and continued our journey back to where we had been an hour earlier. I was super excited as we have been to Do in New York and thought it was amazing. 
Two of us arrived at this new location for DOUGHP, it had just opened the day before, and to my shock, there was no line. Awesome, we walked straight up, made an order, and were out. I went with the original chocolate chip cookie dough and my partner in crime went with the nutella one. We walked around the small store, saw they have a cute little balcony, and some seating inside. We went on our way, eating our cookie dough and about three bites in, we both felt like there was something missing. We weren't able to really place the taste difference, but it left something to be desired. While I finished my cookie dough, his was a little too strong and we threw half of it away. I would definitely choose Do over DOUGHP, but if I'm in the area, I would probably give it another shot. Additionally, they had an option to cook the dough into a cookie at the store, which I thought was a pretty cool idea. Maybe I will try that next time.
author: Amanda P.

description: Drove an hour from Santa Rosa, enjoyed every bite of the delish dough. If your wanting a fun little adventure on a weekend/day off - the pier 39 is the place to be and to satisfy your sweet tooth!
author: Tatiana P.

description:
The effective real-life equivalent of a dispensary for Cookie Monster.

Really novel stand that appears to be at Spark Social SF every now and then.  I've been unfairly lured in a couple times by the troughs of decadent cookie dough [accompanied by a friendly attendant].

It's delicious and whimsical for sure, however given the very dense, sweet, and rich nature of cookie dough, it's not the kind of thing that I found could be eaten in the portion sizes offered -- at least not without help.  Bring help... or Cookie Monster.
author: Dan C.

description:
Food kiosk in the middle of a food market hall, quick service and a few options of dough flavors.  One scoop is plenty and probably best eaten from a cup (as the cookie dough ball tends to roll right off the top of the cone).

This place was built for Instagram, and to induce a sugar coma, but it's a nice spot for a one time visit.
author: Shannon E.

description:
Cookie dough...everybody's favorite snack to steal from the kitchen counter while baking as a kid. But whereas you could only eat little bits during those moments, Doughp gives you entire scoops to eat.

At first, the bites are heavenly. You get a mouthful of creamy, sweet, and very very sugary cookie dough. It's absolutely divine when it's in your mouth, and you just drop yourself into your childhood and let your brain feel the comfort. 

At least for me, the cookie dough ended up being way too heavy and sugary. Even with just one scoop, towards the end I was stuffing down the last bits that I knew I could not waste. But overall, the cookie dough experience was awesome. As the saying goes, too much of a good thing will make it bad, and that certainly happened for me. I would have to say that if I drank something while eating the cookie dough it would have been much better, so definitely try it with milk and see if it changes the experience.
author: Michael Y.

description: We thought this was going to be a huge hit, but we were wrong. It was super sugary and slightly warm. Not at all what we were expecting.
author: Angela R.

description: Came here on a friends recommendation and had high expectations. I left very disappointed. I even ended up throwing it away after two bites, which I rarely ever do. It tasted like cookie dough that had been sitting out for the past week. Extremely dry. Overall, I can say that I definitely won't be back. I like the idea of edible cookie dough but not when it tastes like that.
author: Keenan R.

description: Stopped by here on a Saturday afternoon and it wasn't too busy at the time but it started to fill up as I was leaving. I ordered a scoop of the s'mores cookie dough in a bowl -- I really wanted it in a fun flavored cone but there were only matcha cones at the time unfortunately. I am a person who truly enjoys eating raw cookie dough so I was really excited that I would be able to try DOUGHP as I have been following them on Instagram for some time; their new location at the Pier is very convenient and I'm glad I was able to stop by. My boyfriend and sister who were also with me at the time (and decidedly less excited than me about the prospect of eating a mass amount of raw cookie dough with a spoon) did not order anything. Overall I thought the cookie dough was good and the storefront is very cute and "instagram-able." It tasted even better than I thought it would, I just wish it was a little less pricey. $7.05 for one scoop of cookie dough and a drizzle of marshmallow cream seems a little steep so, yes while it was delicious, it's probably not a place I would make a habit to stop by regularly.
author: Tayler K.

description:
Second floor on the Pier. Almost walked by it, until my husband said it wasn't an ice cream shop, but cookie dough. Of course my preggo self couldn't say no to that. 

Recommend to have it with a glass of milk. It's not listed on the menu - but they have it. Would most definitely come back again!
author: Eileen N.

description: Pier 39 has the BEST edible cookie dough - I love the Eminem dough!  You can relax, an eat your dough while people watching from the outdoor patio - it's a great spot!  Definitely get some dough, and take some home too!
author: Todd C.

description:
So many different options of flavors! Come here if you want to impress your friends or go on a cute mini date. Parking was low-key hard to find but I somehow finessed it. Atmosphere was so chill, with other surrounding mini shops which felt like a mini homey market place. 

The worker was so nice to me. Catering to anything I wanted such as giving me samples, she even asked how my day was going which was pretty nice. It was my first time going to any 'dough' place so I was clueless on what to order, but she walked my friend and I through what DOUGHP actually is. 

But only come here after you've eaten dinner as a dessert. Although I ordered one scoop with a flavored cone, I was already full! 

Go to this joint. Whenever I visit Castro, definitely coming back!
author: Patrick O.

description:
I'm gonna be straight up and start off this review by saying the cookie dough was not at all tasty in any way. I'm actually quite SHOCKED that this place has such good reviews! I am an avid cookie dough lover, I make homemade cookies weekly just so I can eat the dough. Because of this, I had this place on my to do in SF ever since it opened. When I went to the city last week for the first time in a while, of course I made a stop at DOUGHP. When I went in the store, it was super cute with its little neon sign and decor. I tried three of the cookie doughs (there was only five flavors, and no unique ones such as snickerdoodle or s'mores or any actual fun flavors) and all three I tried basically tasted the same. I was disappointed, but I ordered a cup anyways and got sprinkles and chocolate sauce to help add some flavor to the very bland cookie dough I had tried in the sample. Unfortunately the toppings did not help. I probably had 4 small bites of the dough (small size) before I decided it wasn't worth the calories. I was really rooting for this place but honestly the lack of selection and the boring tasting cookie dough was just not good. It's a total tourist trap, as it trapped me, but I will definitely not spend money here again sadly. I'm honestly really disappointed!

EDIT: I didn't realize it was a bad day and they didn't have two of their most popular flavors. Given that I'll bump my rating up to a 3 for good customer service and I'll have to go back and try again after they've figured out the kinks
author: Macy W.

description: MUST HAVE THE DOUGHP LATTE!!! Honestly the BEST latte I've EVER had. It's topped with whipping cream and choc sprinkles with a scoop of cookie dough in the bottom that melts in your mouth at the end. I tried the elder rose dough with it and it was BOMB. This location is super cool with a wicked balcony on the far side. The staff are super friendly and the value for money was totally worth it. Will be back! And as you can see the kids LOVED it too
author: Monica M.

description: This was my first experience at a cookie dough bar. It was so good! When we walked in, we were greeted and offered samples. The aesthetic of the shop was awesome and trendy with a cute neon sign. I made the mistake of ordering two scoops because I thought I could eat it all, but it was too rich. I didn't want to throw it away so I walked back to the store and the girls gave me a take home container. They were super nice, I wish I got their names!
author: Cassidy M.

description:
I was so intrigued with Doughp that I wanted them to be part of the International Chocolate Festival. And they didn't disappoint. Not only did they sell out the first day, they went back and brought more the second day - and sold out again. At least I got to sample it myself!!

The people were wonderful, responsive, and very professional - with a sassy sense of humor. Which is so appreciated.
author: Pamm M.

description: This was a dream come true. I loved every flavor of cookie dough but setlltled on peanut butter chocolate chip because I had to choose just one. Put it in a nutella chocolate waffle cone... it was so incredibly delicious. That gals working were sweet as can be... the vibe and cute little outside spot were great. Love the name too. I mean. Doughp. Brilliant.
author: Vanessa A.

description:
